Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Genomic architecture of adaptive radiation: a role for gene duplication among African cichlid radiations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gene duplication and the subsequent evolution of the duplicates is an important source of genetic and functional novelty in all three domains of life. As the African cichlid fishes have undergone rapid, recent and repeated speciation events, they constitute an ideal model with which to test long-standing hypotheses about the role of gene duplication in evolutionary expansion, speciation and adaptation to the environment. This project will employ modern genomic techniques using genomic hybridization to identify duplicated genes. Gene duplicate number, gene duplication rate and retention of gene duplicates from specific functional categories will be investigated for an association with enhanced speciation as well as ecological diversification. Sequence analysis of duplicated genes across this group of fishes will address the degree to which natural selection is responsible for the evolution of gene duplicates.

In addition to the significant contribution to genomic resources for the cichlid research community, this project also advances a broad range of studies concerning the evolution of duplicated genes and their contribution to diversity and adaptation. The project, conducted at Reed College, will strengthen the genomics/bioinformatics program, capitalizing upon the PIs interdisciplinary collaborations. The cutting edge techniques and manipulation of large datasets will provide a rigorous training through the formation of an interdisciplinary research team involving undergraduate students of mathematics and biology. Furthermore, the research will be directly linked with the PIs teaching in Comparative Functional Genomics and will be incorporated into outreach teaching modules on animal diversity and genome evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Adaptive radiation is an evolutionary process by which multiple rapid speciation events result in remarkable phenotypic diversity within a clade. Similarly, gene duplication is a prominent feature of molecular evolution that results in remarkable evolutionary novelty among gene families. Although the adaptive potential for gene duplicates was recognized by early geneticists, and theoretical work was advanced in the 1970’s, little empirical evidence has been available until recently. East African cichlids, are a textbook example of adaptive radiation. Both recent genomic sequence information and our own array based comparative genomic hybridization (aCGH) now reveal that these fishes possess an unexpectedly large number of gene duplicates. The aCGH analyses reveal a highly variable number of recent duplicated genes across the 4 non-tilapia cichlid species relative to O. niloticus. Among the total of 852 genes determined to be in increased copy number in one or more of the 4 species relative to tilapia, about 50% (n = 437) are detected in only a single species and 15% (n = 132) were shared among all 4 species. Considering the duplications detected by aCGH in the phylogenetic context, we found the highest rates of duplication retention in the 2 species representing clades that have undergone adaptive radiation and lower rates of duplicate retention in the non-radiating river species.  We compared our results to two other methods applied to these same 5 cichlid with somewhat variable but complementary results. Gene/species tree reconciliation analysis is aimed at identifying duplicated genes that have already diverged sequence while Read-Depth analysis is aimed detecting gene duplicates that do not differ substantially in sequence. Therefore, due to the constraints and goals of gene duplication detection methods it was not surprising to find a low level of overlap among the three sets identified. This highlights the need for parallel analyses to reveal the complete story. By surveying >50 different species using aCGH technique we quantify gene duplicates across a broader phylogenetic range than is possible with the other techniques.  This work was conducted at Reed College primarily by undergraduate summer research students. The analysis was conducted collaboration with phylogeneticists at the University of Hull. The work has been presented by students at multiple conferences. Using similar techniques adapted for the classroom, a teaching module was developed and employed at Reed College.
